characters.description: Gatsby's house lights are no longer on, marking the end of his extravagant parties. He fires his servants to prevent gossip about Daisy's visits.
Nick visits Gatsby to check on him and is later invited to lunch at Daisy's. He observes the interactions and tensions between the characters.
The unfamiliar butler is rude and suspicious when Nick visits Gatsby's house. He informs Nick that Gatsby is not sick.
Finn informs Nick that Gatsby fired all his servants and replaced them with new ones.
Daisy is having an affair with Gatsby and visits him frequently. She invites Nick to lunch and later suggests going to town.
Wolfshiem is mentioned as the person who wanted to help the people who are now Gatsby's servants.
Jordan is present at Daisy's house and observes the interactions between Daisy, Gatsby, and Tom. She accompanies them to town.
Tom is suspicious of Gatsby and Daisy's relationship and confronts them. He insists on driving Gatsby's car to town.
A woman on the train is affected by the heat and drops her pocketbook.
The conductor remarks on the heat to the passengers on the train.
The butler at the Buchanans' house announces the arrival of Gatsby and Nick and takes their hats.
Pammy is Daisy and Tom's daughter, who is briefly introduced during the luncheon. Gatsby is surprised by her existence.
The nurse leads Pammy into the room and takes her away.
Wilson is the owner of a garage and is sick and wants to leave town with his wife. He suspects his wife is having an affair.
Myrtle is Wilson's wife and Tom's mistress, who is planning to leave to the West. She is seen peering jealously at Jordan from the window of the garage.
